label: 部
本: The Emergence of Japanese Kingship . Stanford University Press . 1997
説明文: a specialized worker community that provided services to the Yamato throne, to a senior consort or prince, or perhaps to an uji in the fifth through seventh centuries. The practice is widely thought to have been imported from the continent, and early be may well have been groups of immigrants from the Korean peninsula who served the Yamato ruler in various capacities-as cultivators (tabe 田部), artisans, guards, pastoralists, etc. Typically, a be community was overseen by a hereditary chieftain known as a tomo-no-miyatsuko, who was subject to a courtier possessing the title muraji 連, Koshiro 子代 were communities of dependent specialized worker-cultivators, guards, and other providers that served Yamato kings and other royals, especially consorts and their offspring, from the fifth through seventh centuries. They included mibube, attached to palaces of consorts and royal princes, and other service groups known as toneribe, kashiwadebe, and yugeibe. Through the staffing and management of such groups, members of the chieftain stratum across the archipelago provided service to the Great King.
